docBody.p: valuation of the new shoots, which are springing up in Society today toward the Marriage system is to consider the history of marriage.
Page (395) Ellis--on Woman's status in Rome--
In the later days of Roman Empire women had acquired an independent position nearly equal to their husbands while the patriarchal authority over them was almost nominal.

In Roman law there was no legal forms of marriage--it was considered a fact not a legal form, and living together a year constituted a marriage & regarded just as complete & legal as if it had been inaugurated by the Confarreatio. It was considered a private agreement in which man & woman approached each other on a footing of equality. The wife controlled full rights of her property & divorce was also a private transaction to which both husband & wife were entitled without the interruption of courts. Ellis says “it is interesting to note this enlightened conception of marriage prevailing in the greatest & most masterful Empire which has ever dominated the world.”

After the face of the Roman Empire the Roman law remained as a standard for new developing nations, but its become influenced by & with Christianity which gradually & subteley revealed a growing ascetic feeling hostile to the dignity of the married woman & the freedom of marriage & divorce. With this was introduced the Jewish Marriage system (barbaric) which gave to the husband rights in marriage & divorce but denied them to the wife.

The German ideas regarding marriage were even more primitive & barbaric than that of the Jews and involved the wife as a husband’s chattel & marriage as a purchase, all these influences clashed but the result was that the fifteen hundred years which followed the conquest of Christianity represent the most degraded condition to which the marriage system has ever been known to fall for so long a period during the whole course of human history.
Sale marriage was the usual form & the ring was a form of the bride price or a "arrha" which was money in this contract is the symbol of it.

At first the ring was a sign of the brides purchase, but later it acquired the significance of subjection to the bridegroom & was later emphasized by other ceremonies. Some forms of England & York marriages direct the bride to fall at the feet of the husband & kiss his right foot at the delivery of the ring.
The influence of the Catholic Church over marriage has been handed over to us for the tenth century. Earlier than the sixth Century there was no special religious service.

The Christian Church at first accepted the forms of marriage already existing in these countries in which it found itself, it demanded that it should be hallowed by priestly benediction the same as was demanded for all other civil contracts. But marriage was recognized by the Church even in the absence of such benediction.

A special marriage service developed slowly. At first the first part of the nuptials was performed outside the Church door & was followed by the bride mass of the occasion during the tenth century & gradually at the twelfth century the priest directed the ceremony inside the Church & in the 13 Century the priest directed officiated the whole ceremony. Up to this time marriage had been a purely private business transaction--a thousand years after of Christianity through the slow growth of custom Church marriage was established. Today the public method of marriage is based on the marriage form of the twelfth century.
